item.title: Summer Break
item.dc:creator: bretspears
item.content:encoded:
Well it seems that summer life with all three kids home every day and a 20 month-old who loves to climb leaves little time for writing. So, we're going to officially break until mid-August when the big kids <del>are someone else's problem</del> go to school.
Cheers-
Bret

item.title: The Side Effects of Doing Blue Apron: Spears Family Review
item.dc:creator: maryspears
item.content:encoded:
I never really cooked before we had kids. I mean, not really at all. Side rant: What's up with that, anyway? How, in what conceivable way, could it be considered a "masculine" trait to be UNABLE to prepare your own food? I'm not saying that's how I saw it, but think about it... Last time I checked, food was pretty important for survival and (you would think) the ability to survive would be a significantly manly attribute. I digress. We married pretty young and my wife is a profoundly gifted cook (something for which I should thank my mother-in-law). I was spoiled, you might say. But, as we began to have children and my role as the primary caregiver became more and more familiar, it became clear that I needed to "up my game" in the kitchen. I started with breakfast. And, by the time our third child was born, I had become reasonably adequate. Lunch is lunch. Dinnertime, though. That was a barrel I was not yet ready to stare down... My wife, Mary, loves to cook, but doesn't have the time due to work; I needed to expand my culinary abilities, but didn't have a teacher. Meal-planning and grocery-getting can be tricky with a young brood such as ours. Dinner time had started to lose its luster. The most trying hour in our home had become the hour that Mary came in the door from work, was tackled immediately by the children, then had to quickly get on the task of making dinner while holding our youngest.Â  Our two-year-old, Boston, LOVES to cook.Â  If something is being prepared, he wants to cut, saute and stir right along side the cookâ¦all while turning all the burner knobs to the wrong temperature when weâre not looking.Â  So, this is what Mary looked like trying to make dinner: (Pic of me cutting with Bossy in the ergo.) Enter Blue Apron. The meals are thought-out for us and delivered to the door, thus putting that time back into our family life. We are only sent what we need, so waste is never an issue- something we positively love. I have step-by-step instructions that alleviate all intimidation and fear of failing, so my knowledge base and skill is steadily increasing. I can do the prep work before my wife gets home and she is able to enjoy cooking again.Â  Or, I can prepare the whole meal.Â Â  In short, it has been very impactful for us. And, the food is fantastic. I'm no Chef Boyardee (yet), but I am making strides and, best of all, I've made one more small step toward becoming a better husband and father. That's the cool thing about earning your blue apron: all you have to do is begin. Since Mary is more of our âlogisticsâ chief around here, Iâm going to let her explain the nuts and bolts: [hr gap="20"] Mary here. If you havenât heard of Blue Apron, Green Chef, Plated, or Hello Fresh, then Iâm not sure Facebook marketing is doing its job. Chances are, youâve heard of them and have been curious. Over the last year, Bret and I have tried hard to identify the areas that are tripping us up and find a solution. Dinner prep was one of those areas that had become more "trying" than "enjoyable". We thought a meal service might help and set out to give it a whirl. In early 2015, we tried Blue Apron, Green Chef, and Hello Fresh. They are all delivery services that send a box with recipes and all the ingredients you need to prepare the meals. After a few months of swapping between all three, we settle on Blue Apron as our favorite for a couple reasons. The food was the best tasting, the most affordable, and had the biggest portions. Hereâs some of my favorite things about Blue Apron:
  • Recipe cards: the recipes are gorgeous and easy-to-follow. Blue Apron also makes all their recipes available online to anyone, not just subscribers (the other guys donât do that). So, if I skip a week because weâll be out of town but really want to try the recipe, I can.
